questionList.questionText: A 78-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to urinary incontinence.  The patient has a history of Alzheimer dementia and has been living in a nursing home for the past 3 years.  At baseline, she requires assistance for most daily activities but is able to alert the nursing home staff when she needs to use the bathroom.  For the past week, the patient has had urinary incontinence, which she has never experienced before; she has also been less active and now spends most of the day sleeping.  Temperature is 36.7 C (98.1 F), blood pressure is 130/70 mm Hg, and pulse is 76/min.  On examination, the patient is somnolent but responsive to voice.  She is disoriented but has a normal gait and no focal neurologic deficits.  The abdomen is soft and nontender.  Genitourinary examination shows thin, pale vaginal mucosa with ill-defined labia minora.  There is mild anterior vaginal wall prolapse.  The remainder of the physical examination is unremarkable.  Which of the following is the best next step in managing this patient's urinary incontinence?
questionList.explanationText:
Urinary incontinence: major causes in older adults

Reversible
(often acute)

Delirium: decreased awareness
Infection (urinary tract): bladder irritation
Atrophic vaginitis: urethral irritation
Pharmacologic: variable mechanisms (eg, anticholinergics, diuretics)
Psychiatric: decreased motivation (eg, depression)
Excess urine output: polyuria (eg, diabetes mellitus)
Reduced mobility (ie, functional): inability to reach toilet (eg, restraints)
Stool (constipation/impaction): urethral or bladder compression

Persistent

  • Urologic causes
    • Stress: pelvic muscle weakness (eg, multiparity)
    • Urgency: detrusor overactivity
    • Mixed: both stress & urgency
    • Overflow: detrusor underactivity or urethral obstruction (eg, BPH)
  • Neurologic causes
    • Urge: detrusor overactivity from impaired CNS inhibition (eg, dementia, Parkinson disease, normal pressure hydrocephalus)
    • Urge ± overflow: mechanism varies by lesion location (eg, multiple sclerosis, spinal cord injury, stroke)

BPH = benign prostatic hyperplasia.

This older patient has acute urinary incontinence.  New-onset incontinence should prompt investigation for reversible causes, which include Delirium, urinary tract Infection (UTI), Atrophic vaginitis, Pharmacology (eg, anticholinergics), Psychiatry (eg, depression), Excess urine (eg, diabetes mellitus), Reduced mobility, and Stool symptoms (eg, constipation) (mnemonic: DIAPPERS).

Etiology can often be identified by history and physical examination.  Because UTI is a common cause of urinary incontinence, urinalysis with urine culture should be obtained for most patients.  This is particularly true for older patients, who may lack typical UTI symptoms/signs (eg, dysuria, fever) or cannot provide a reliable history (eg, dementia).  Positive urine cultures require assessment for asymptomatic bacteriuria versus true infection.  This patient's positive cultures would likely represent true infection given that UTI could explain both her new-onset incontinence and delirium (eg, increased somnolence).

If reversible causes are not found, further testing includes evaluation for stress incontinence (eg, Valsalva maneuver with full bladder) and overflow incontinence (eg, postvoid residual).  Urodynamic testing is usually unnecessary unless there is diagnostic uncertainty (eg, mixed incontinence) or consideration for surgical intervention (Choice E).

(Choice A)  Beta-3 adrenergic agonists (eg, mirabegron) promote detrusor relaxation and are effective for urge incontinence (ie, overactive bladder).  However, pharmacotherapy is typically not initiated until reversible causes are excluded and the incontinence type is clarified.

(Choice B)  CT scan of the head can evaluate for neurologic causes of urinary incontinence (eg, stroke, normal pressure hydrocephalus [NPH]).  Despite this patient's altered mental status, she has no focal neurologic findings to suggest acute stroke.  Although urinary incontinence and dementia are cardinal features of NPH, this patient's lack of gait dysfunction (typically the most prominent feature) makes NPH unlikely.

(Choice C)  Long-term urinary catheter placement is typically reserved for patients with chronic urinary incontinence (or retention) who cannot manage intermittent self-catheterization.  It is inappropriate for this patient's acute urinary incontinence and would likely exacerbate her delirium.

(Choice F)  Vaginal estrogen cream is effective for atrophic vaginitis (eg, pale, thin mucosa), which is common in postmenopausal patients.  Although atrophic vaginitis is a reversible cause of urinary incontinence, it would not explain this patient's acute onset and associated delirium.

Educational objective:
Acute urinary incontinence should prompt investigation for reversible causes.  Because urinary tract infection is a common reversible cause, urinalysis with urine culture is appropriate for most patients.  This is particularly true in older patients who may lack typical signs/symptoms or cannot provide a reliable history (eg, dementia).

questionList.questionText: A 40-year-old woman comes to the emergency department due to abdominal pain for the past 2 weeks.  The pain has become worse over the past day and is not relieved by ibuprofen.  The patient has a fever but no nausea, vomiting, diarrhea, or dysuria.  She has no chronic medical conditions or previous surgeries.  Her last menstrual period was 2 weeks ago; menses are regular and last 5 days, with painful cramping and heavy bleeding on the first day.  The patient is sexually active with a male partner and uses condoms for contraception.  She does not use tobacco, alcohol, or illicit drugs.  Temperature is 38.8 C (101.8 F), blood pressure is 100/60 mm Hg, and pulse is 92/min.  The abdomen has diffuse tenderness to deep palpation that is worse in the right lower quadrant.  There is no rebound or guarding.  Pelvic examination reveals a small, mobile, tender uterus and an enlarged, tender right adnexal mass.  Leukocyte count is 22,000/mm3.  Urine pregnancy test is negative.  Pelvic ultrasonography reveals a large, thick-walled, multiloculated mass filled with debris obliterating the right adnexa.  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Pelvic inflammatory disease

Symptoms

  • Lower abdominal pain
  • Abnormal bleeding

Risk
factors

  • Multiple sexual partners
  • Age 15-25
  • Previous pelvic inflammatory disease
  • Inconsistent barrier contraception use
  • Partner with sexually transmitted infection

Physical
examination

  • Fever >38.3 C (>100.9 F)
  • Cervical motion, uterine, or adnexal tenderness
  • Mucopurulent cervical discharge

Treatment

  • Inpatient: IV broad-spectrum antibiotics
  • Outpatient: PO broad-spectrum antibiotics

Complications

  • Tuboovarian abscess
  • Infertility
  • Ectopic pregnancy
  • Perihepatitis

This patient with fever, abdominal pain, and a multiloculated, complex adnexal mass most likely has a tuboovarian abscess (TOA).  TOA typically occurs in sexually active, reproductive-age women as a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease, a polymicrobial infection of the upper genital tract (ie, uterus, fallopian tubes).

Patients with TOA can initially have diffuse lower abdominal pain plus uterine tenderness that gradually (over days to weeks) worsens and localizes to one side, causing unilateral adnexal tenderness with an associated mass.  Because of the worsening infection, patients often develop high fever and leukocytosis.  When the infection extends to the fallopian tube, it creates an inflammatory exudate, purulent fluid, and tubal wall thickening, which conglomerate into a complex adnexal mass, or pyosalpinx (ie, infected fallopian tube), visible on pelvic ultrasound.  Treatment is with intravenous broad-spectrum antibiotics.

(Choice A)  An appendiceal abscess can cause fever, pain, and a mass in the right lower quadrant.  However, patients typically have periumbilical pain that migrates to the right lower quadrant with associated nausea, vomiting, and anorexia.

(Choice B)  Endometriosis can present with abdominal pain and an adnexal mass (eg, endometrioma) that is typically described as having a ground-glass appearance on ultrasound.  However, high fever, uterine tenderness, and leukocytosis are not typically present.

(Choice C)  A mature cystic teratoma may present with abdominal pain (due to mass effect or acute torsion) but does not cause fever and leukocytosis.  Ultrasound typically reveals an ovarian cyst with solid components, hyperechoic nodules, and calcifications.

(Choice D)  Ovarian serous cystadenocarcinomas are the most common type of ovarian cancer.  They can cause abdominal pain and inflammation (eg, fever, leukocytosis) due to ovarian necrosis; however, patients do not typically have both uterine and adnexal tenderness.

(Choice E)  Although ovarian torsion can cause abdominal pain and fever due to ovarian necrosis, the initial onset of pain is typically sudden and unilateral rather than diffuse.  Ultrasound typically shows an adnexal mass with absent Doppler flow.

Educational objective:
A tuboovarian abscess is a complication of pelvic inflammatory disease, a polymicrobial infection of the upper genital tract.  Patients typically have fever, diffuse abdominal pain that gradually worsens on one side, and both uterine and adnexal tenderness.  Ultrasound typically shows a complex multiloculated adnexal mass with thick walls and internal debris.

questionList.questionText: A 21-year-old woman is brought to the emergency department due to a day of persistent vomiting, diarrhea, and high fever.  The patient also has had a severe headache unrelieved by acetaminophen.  She has no hematemesis or hematochezia.  The patient spent the past 3 months in Southeast Asia and returned yesterday after 36 hours of plane travel and airport layovers.  She has no chronic medical conditions or previous surgeries.  The patient does not use tobacco or recreational drugs.  She is currently on day 5 of her menstrual period.  Temperature is 39.4 C (102.9 F), blood pressure is 80/40 mm Hg, and pulse is 124/min.  Physical examination shows a diaphoretic woman with dry mucous membranes.  There is no nuchal rigidity.  An erythematous macular rash covers the entire body, including the palms and soles.  Which of the following microorganisms is most likely responsible for this patient's symptoms?
questionList.explanationText:
Staphylococcal toxic shock syndrome

Risks

  • Tampon use
  • Nasal packing
  • Surgical/postpartum wound infection

Pathogenesis

  • Staphylococcus aureus
  • Exotoxin release acting as superantigens

Clinical
features

  • Fever >38.9 C (102 F)
  • Hypotension
  • Diffuse macular rash involving palms & soles
  • Desquamation 1-3 weeks after disease onset
  • Vomiting, diarrhea
  • Altered mentation without focal neurologic signs

Treatment

  • Supportive therapy (fluid replacement)
  • Removal of foreign body (eg, tampon)
  • Antibiotic therapy (eg, vancomycin, cefepime, clindamycin)

This patient with fever, signs of shock (eg, hypotension, tachycardia), and a diffuse erythematous rash likely has toxic shock syndrome (TSS).  TSS typically occurs when an exotoxin-producing strain of Staphylococcus aureus proliferates in a retained foreign body (eg, tampon, nasal/wound packing) or a wound infection (eg, surgical, post-partum); this patient likely developed TSS due to prolonged tampon use during her travel home from Southeast Asia.

Certain S aureus exotoxins (eg, TSS toxin-1) act as superantigens, proteins that bypass normal antigen processing and bind directly to the surface of class II major histocompatibility complexes.  Superantigens indiscriminately activate T cells, leading to the massive release of inflammatory cytokines.  Manifestations of TSS typically arise rapidly over 1-2 days and include fever, shock, a widespread macular rash that eventually desquamates (usually after 1-2 weeks), and multiorgan failure (eg, decreased urine output, altered mentation).  Treatment includes supportive care (eg, intravenous fluids), removal of the foreign body (if still present), and empiric antibiotic therapy (vancomycin, cefepime, and clindamycin).

(Choice A)  Disseminated gonococcal infection (DGI) can cause a pustular rash.  A widespread macular rash is not seen.  In addition, most patients with DGI who have a rash also have tenosynovitis and migratory polyarthralgia.  Furthermore, shock is uncommon.

(Choice B)  Rotavirus can cause traveler's diarrhea.  In adults, this typically presents with mild gastroenteritis (eg, watery diarrhea, dry mucous membranes).  However, Rotavirus does not cause rash, and shock would be very uncommon.

(Choice C)  Shigella gastroenteritis causes fever, bloody diarrhea, and abdominal cramping but not rash.

(Choice E)  Secondary syphilis, caused by Treponema pallidum, can present with a maculopapular rash involving the palms and soles.  Patients may also develop a low fever, malaise, and epitrochlear adenopathy.  However, patients typically have an indolent course, and shock would be very uncommon.

Educational objective:
Toxic shock syndrome (TSS) is usually due to the elaboration of Staphylococcus aureus exotoxin.  Most cases are associated with a retained foreign body (eg, tampon, nasal packing) or a skin/soft-tissue infection.  TSS typically presents with fever, shock, and a diffuse, red, macular rash involving the palms and soles.  Treatment includes fluid replacement, removal of the foreign body (if present), and empiric antibiotic therapy.

questionList.questionText:
Patient Information
Age: 19 years
Gender: F, self-identified
Race/Ethnicity: unspecified
Site of Care: office

History
Reason for Visit/Chief Concern: amenorrhea

History of Present Illness:

  • 5 months of amenorrhea
  • previously had regular menses every 28 days with 4-5 days of bleeding
  • menarche at age 14
  • no headaches, visual disturbances, heat intolerance, palpitations, hot flashes, or night sweats

Past Medical History:

  • no chronic medical conditions

Medications:

  • no current medications

Allergies:

  • no known drug allergies

Family History:

  • noncontributory

Psychosocial History:

  • national gymnastics champion; attends the local university
  • has never been sexually active
  • does not use tobacco, alcohol, or recreational drugs

Physical Examination

TempPulseRespBPO2 SatHtWtBMI
36.7 C
(98.1 F)		54/min–110/60
mm Hg		98% on
room air		165 cm
(5 ft 4 in)		–19 kg/m2
  • Appearance: in no acute distress; muscular appearing
  • HEENT: mild facial acne; no thyromegaly or facial hair
  • Cardiac: regular rhythm; normal S1 and S2
  • Breast: sexual maturity rating (Tanner stage) 5 development
  • Abdominal: soft, nontender; no palpable masses
  • Pelvic: normal external genitalia, vagina, and cervix; small, mobile uterus; no adnexal masses on bimanual examination

Diagnostic Studies

  • Urine pregnancy test: negative
  • TSH and prolactin levels: within normal limits

Question:  Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis in this patient?
questionList.explanationText:
Exercise-induced hypothalamic amenorrhea

Clinical presentation

  • Strenuous exercise
  • Relative calorie deficiency
  • Stress fracture
  • Amenorrhea
  • Infertility

Hormone levels

  • ↓ GnRH
  • ↓ LH & FSH
  • ↓ Estrogen

Long-term consequences

  • ↓ Bone mineral density
  • ↑ Total cholesterol
  • ↑ Triglycerides

Treatment

  • Increased calorie intake
  • Estrogen
  • Calcium & vitamin D

This conditioned athlete has secondary amenorrhea likely due to functional hypothalamic amenorrhea (eg, hypogonadotropic hypogonadism), which is commonly seen in women with the athlete's triad: amenorrhea, osteoporosis, and insufficient caloric intake.

Female athletes who exercise intensively are thought to have a relative caloric deficiency (even those with normal BMI) secondary to insufficient calorie replenishment compared to the amount of energy expended.  Low energy stores (ie, low body fat) in muscular athletes (as seen in this patient) also alter multiple peripheral metabolic hormones (ie, low leptin, high ghrelin), which affects GnRH secretion.  These combined effects suppress the hypothalamic-pituitary-ovarian axis with decreased levels of GnRH, a subsequent decrease in LH secretion, and ultimately estrogen deficiency.

These patients are at increased risk for conditions associated with estrogen deficiency, including infertility and decreased bone mineral density (eg, osteopenia).

(Choices A and B)  Androgenic steroid use and congenital adrenal hyperplasia present with virilization (eg, male pattern baldness, deepening voice, clitoromegaly) and hypertension.  Patients who use androgenic steroids also exhibit aggressive behavior and mood disorders, which are not seen in this patient.

(Choice D)  Ovarian fibrothecoma, a type of ovarian sex cord–stromal tumor, may secrete androgens but more commonly secretes estrogen.  This patient has no evidence of excess androgen (eg, hirsutism) or estrogen (eg, breast tenderness) secretion and no adnexal mass.

(Choice E)  Patients with polycystic ovary syndrome have signs of androgen excess (eg, severe nodulocystic acne on the chest and back), obesity, and enlarged ovaries on examination.  This patient has mild acne, but her normal BMI and pelvic examination make this diagnosis less likely.

(Choice F)  Patients with primary ovarian insufficiency typically have vasomotor symptoms (eg, hot flashes, night sweats) and vaginal atrophy associated with amenorrhea.  Primary ovarian insufficiency is typically associated with a concomitant autoimmune disorder or Turner syndrome.

Educational objective:
Secondary amenorrhea is relatively common in female athletes and results from hypothalamic amenorrhea (eg, GnRH deficiency).  The subsequent decreased LH secretion and estrogen deficiency result in amenorrhea and decreased bone mineral density.

questionList.title: Amenorrhea
